title: 106_hr4730
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, are recognized as political successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. With over 2,500 eligible members, they chose not to be removed and continue to operate as a sovereign tribe in Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, chose not to be removed and operate as a sovereign tribe. Despite facing challenges in obtaining Federal recognition, they continue their political and social existence with a viable tribal government. Despite the denial of their petition in 1981, the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia has been recognized by the Federal Government, the government of the State of Georgia, and local governments as leaders of a distinct political entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Tribe or an individual on the membership rolls. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Tribe, making them eligible for all Federal benefits and services available to federally recognized Indian tribes. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5 of the Act establishes a reservation for the Tribe by allowing the Secretary to take land into trust for them within 2 years. Gaming is prohibited on the trust land. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL.

The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution and Bill of Rights. Future membership is limited to lineal descendants of those on the base roll who maintain political relations with the Tribe.

SEC. 7. JURISDICTION.

The reservation established by the Act falls under Federal and tribal jurisdiction.

SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED. The reservation established by this Act is considered Indian country under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. This Act does not affect any treaties or rights secured to the tribes mentioned in the Act.
